body: @tqchen It Is ok for us (tiny-dnn).. I don't know if it is limited to Tensor for naming cause we are already talking about ops interfaces.

If you want an intelligent answer, you should specify relevant details:
* How many physical cores does your CPU have?
* What do you mean by "CPU Number"? The max OpenMP thread number that you are setting via `OMP_THREAD_NUM`? or one of these: http://mxnet.io/how_to/env_var.html

One hypothesis: your machine has four physical cores, and when setting a higher thread number than 4, launching more threads means using hyperthreading, which can cause performance problems.
I think we are not restricted to tensor for naming, I just proposed one because I am kinda of running out of ideas for naming, so please suggest names
`CTensor` sounds good to me

For people looking at this in the future, you can set `ignore_label=-1` in SoftmaxOutput and `use_ignore=True` and then when that label is passed in it will ignore that sample.
Using the two above suggestions sped up my code back to the original amount. Thank you!

I did not find a solution to this other than using `NaiveEngine` to make predictions. I'm imagining that this is because too many threads are being called and cause the entire thing to get flummoxed. Using `Module` was in fact much slower than parallelizing it using `NaiveEngine` and joblib.
Okay, thanks for your suggestion. I think I've found a solution on the splitting 115M side of things.

Hello, @lincolnBush.
First,

`from mxnet import metric`

then,

`metric = mx.metric.Accuracy()`
`return mod.score(val, metric)`

There are also [other metrics](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py#L128) for you to choose from.

I guess you can implement it like this,
1. use a (N, 2, C, H, W) tensor as the network's input.
2. reshape it to (2*N, C, H, W) and extract features for both images with any CNN you want. The output should be (2*N, M).
3. use slice channel operation to split each image's feature. (2*N, M) -> (N, M) x 2;
4. compute the difference like mx.sym.sum(mx.sym.square(f1-f2)) where f1 and f2 are the two feature vectors in step 3.

i prefer to not use `tensor` because mathematically `tensor` has a rich of properties, while most operators we are using are just elemental-wise, so n-dimensional array is better to name the data structure.

I think you can implement a EvalMetric by yourself,like the example in `/mxnet/example/rcnn/rcnn/core/metric` , code will like this :  
```
    class RPNAccMetric(mx.metric.EvalMetric):
    def __init__(self):
        super(RPNAccMetric, self).__init__('RPNAcc')
        self.pred, self.label = get_rpn_names()

    def update(self, labels, preds):
        pred = preds[self.pred.index('rpn_cls_prob')]
        label = labels[self.label.index('rpn_label')]

        # pred (b, c, p) or (b, c, h, w)
        pred_label = mx.ndarray.argmax_channel(pred).asnumpy().astype('int32')
        pred_label = pred_label.reshape((pred_label.shape[0], -1))
        # label (b, p)
        label = label.asnumpy().astype('int32')

        # filter with keep_inds
        keep_inds = np.where(label != -1)
        pred_label = pred_label[keep_inds]
        label = label[keep_inds]

        self.sum_metric += np.sum(pred_label.flat == label.flat)
        self.num_inst += len(pred_label.flat) 
```  
where the pred is the output of your net ,ingore label is -1. after the eval metric was implemented,you can use it in `module.fit`.

The inability to do such simple things with simple API is one of the key reasons why MXNet is the simplest, the most powerful but not the most popular DL framework. User friendliness has never been a top priority.

TensorFlow & Keras combined have the largest user base and are growing most rapidly. You should bring those guys on board for this proposal to make the biggest impact.

Just two points:
1. Before naming the project, it should be clear about the targets and boundaries of this project clear first: how many issues are there and what issues are to be resolved at what stage.
2. Using an agile method to start from easy targets: those are probably to be resolved quickly and easy to get agreement from all participants.

For GPU support, I've published mxnet-cu80 and mxnet-cu75 which support CUDA8.0 and 7.5 respectively, to replace mxnet-gpu. Both versions use cuDNN5.1.
As a side topic, I personally think how to allow MXNet scale out over micro-kernel multi-server OSes and scale down on limited-battery devices is also important.

@piiswrong: have you done any benchmarking comparing this fused cell to the unrolled cell? We've found that for short sequence lengths (<20) there is not that much speedup (maybe a factor of 2 at most). But for long sequence lengths, the speedup is much more significant. Do you also find this?
